Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Nanotopography Capability at the University of Washington Microfabrication Facility

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: The main objective of this proposal is to acquire an I-line stepper tool for high-throughput lithography with 350 nm feature resolution bridging the gap between electron-beam lithography and contact lithography. Nano-imprint and photolithography are usually done in separate machines and this proposal is to acquire an integrated machine that can do both simultaneously resulting in superior alignment. Numerous exciting projects will benefit from the acquisition of this equipment. Contact guidance studies using nanotopography, creating nanorachets for microfluidics, nanoelectrodes for energy, plasmonics are all high quality projects that will benefit from this acquisition. Overall, the projects are interesting and potentially transformative. The projects are cohesive and will rely on the stepper tool, it is well written and well organized proposal in all aspects. The PIs have the required expertise for use of this instrument in current and future research projects. The proposed tool will have a broad impact in research and education. The combination of projects including junior faculty with senior faculty is unique and well thought of. The acquisition of this tool will benefit the academic researchers and overall users for the UW NNIN node. The outreach efforts are broad and well described including involvement of students from community colleges, high schools and underrepresented minorities. The cleanroom facilities are already funded by NNIN, hence having this tool in the facility not only will serve a larger group of researchers, but also will be maintained well. More than100 academic users and about 40 industrial users are expected to use the tool.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This MRI award established a new capability at the University of Washington in Seattle. With the acquisition of a Canon FPA 3000 i4 i-line lithography stepper, it became possible for a large and diverse group of researchers to create nanotopography in the Washington Nanofabrication Facility (WNF), the central cleanroom laboratory and largest publicly accessible facility of its kind in the Pacific Northwest.

The team of investigators shares the curiosity and excitement about the unique physical, chemical, and biological phenomena occurring at the nanoscale. For instance, they study the interactions of nanotopography with liquid and living matter to create novel devices that

  • process minute amounts of liquids for medical diagnostics
  • provide scaffolds for tissue engineering
  • elucidate the coupled electrokinetic mass transport and charge transfer at nanoelectrodes for electrochemical energy storage, and
  • form components for silicon-based optical computing and communications networks.

The new insights accomplished by this team and enabled by the i-line stepper have already been widely disseminated in top-ranked peer-reviewed journals, such as Nature Nanotechnology, ACS Nano and Microsystems & Nanoengineering (Nature Publishing Group), forming the core of the intellectual merit for this MRI award. These results may lead to novel medical devices and procedures and faster telecommunications systems; several of these efforts have generated intellectual property with high potential for commercialization.

Moreover, the acquisition of the i-line stepper closed a critical gap in the capabilities at the WNF. The MRI commitment from NSF provided leverage to obtain substantial additional resources. In particular, the University of Washington recently committed to a $37M renovation of the WNF. This investment, in turn, contributed to a successful proposal to become one of the 16 sites in the new NSF National Nanotechnology Coordinated Infrastructure (NNCI) network. Through NNCI, the i-line stepper is now accessible to thousands of nanotechnology researchers across the country and beyond. It has not only enabled campus research, but also triggered new research among industrial users at the WNF. Small and large businesses from local start-up Modern Electron to Fortune-100 company Boeing utilize this instrument. Moreover, students trained on the i-line stepper in the WNF learn valuable and unique skills that position them well for advanced technology jobs. The WNF currently employs about 20 undergraduate helpers and trains numerous students and postdocs, and thus plays an important role to create the future workforce for advanced manufacturing with scalable nanotechnology.  


Last Modified: 11/30/2016
Modified by: Karl F Bohringer
